hero.title: Autoimmune Diseases
hero.description:
When your body starts fighting itself. Autoimmune diseases occur when the immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissues instead of protecting the body from infections.

This leads to chronic inflammation, tissue damage, and progressive organ dysfunction.

data.description:
If you’ve been feeling constantly tired, dealing with pain, swelling, rashes, stiffness, or unexplained symptoms — and no one has given you a clear answer — you’re not alone.

Autoimmune diseases are often invisible, confusing, and slow to diagnose. Many people live with symptoms for years before understanding what’s happening inside their body.

data.titleBig:
Your immune system’s job is simple:
Protect you from infections.

But in Autoimmune Disease, something goes wrong.

cards.title: Instead of attacking germs, the immune system:
cards.description:
• Mistakes your own body as a threat
  • Attacks healthy tissues
  • Never fully “switches off”

cards.title: This leads to:
cards.description:
• Long-lasting inflammation
  • Pain and swelling
  • Damage to organs over time

data.titleBig2:
In simple words:
Your body is fighting the wrong battle — and hurting itself.

data.title: Why does this happen?
data.contentHTML:
The exact cause isn’t always clear, but autoimmune diseases are often linked to:

  • Genetics (family history)
  • Infections
  • Hormonal changes
  • Stress
  • Lifestyle and environmental triggers
data.messageHTML: Once triggered, the immune system gets stuck in attack mode.

data.title: What does Autoimmune Disease feel like?
data.contentHTML:
People experience different symptoms, but common ones include:

  • Extreme fatigue (even after rest)
  • Joint pain or morning stiffness
  • Swelling in hands, knees, or feet
  • Skin rashes or sensitivity to sunlight
  • Digestive issues
  • Brain fog or low energy
  • Symptoms that come and go in flares
data.messageHTML:
Many patients say:

I don’t look sick, but I don’t feel normal.

data.headingSmall: Different Autoimmune Diseases, Same Root Problem
data.titleBig: Autoimmune diseases can affect different parts of the body, but the underlying issue is similar.

cards.title: Multi-organ
cards.description:
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
Skin, joints, kidneys, blood, lungs

cards.title: Skin & Organ Hardening
cards.description:
Scleroderma
Tight skin, breathing problems, digestion issues

data.note1: Some people also develop autoimmune conditions that affect the liver, lungs, kidneys, or nerves.
data.titleBig2: Autoimmune diseases can affect different parts of the body, but the underlying issue is similar.

data.title: How Autoimmune Diseases are diagnosed?
data.contentHTML:
Clinical History

  • Genetics (family history)
  • Infections
  • Hormonal changes
  • Stress
  • Lifestyle and environmental triggers

Organ Assessment

  • Urine tests (lupus nephritis)
  • Lung function tests (scleroderma)
  • Liver enzymes and imaging

Physical Examination

  • Joint swelling or deformity
  • Skin rashes or tightening
  • Organ enlargement or tenderness

Blood Reports

  • Screening: ANA (≈90% sensitivity)
  • Autoantibody panels: anti-dsDNA, Sm, RNP, Scl-70, Jo-1
  • Disease-specific:
    • RF / Anti-CCP (RA)
    • Complement levels C3/C4 (SLE)
    • ESR / CRP (Inflammation markers)

data.title: How are Autoimmune Diseases usually treated?
data.contentHTML:
This option is often explored by people who:

  • Steroids
  • Immune-suppressing medicines
  • Advanced injections (biologics)

These treatments can:

  • Reduce symptoms
  • Control flares
data.messageHTML:
But they often:

  • Don’t fix the root cause
  • Need long-term use
  • Increase infection risk
  • Don’t repair damaged tissues

data.contentHTML:
Small daily choices matter:

  • Managing stress and sleep
  • Anti-inflammatory nutrition
  • Vaccination and infection awareness
  • Close care-team collaboration

faqs.question: What exactly is an autoimmune disease?
faqs.answer: An autoimmune disease happens when the immune system, which normally protects you from infections, mistakenly attacks your own body. This can cause ongoing inflammation and symptoms that come and go over time.
